clinical_study.brief_title: Lymphocyte - Monocyte Ratio As An Independent Predictor For Progression Of Illness In Patients With Covid-19
clinical_study.official_title: Lymphocyte - Monocyte Ratio As An Independent Predictor For Progression Of Illness In Patients With Covid-19

lead_sponsor.agency: Postgraduate Institute of Medical Education and Research

clinical_study.source: Postgraduate Institute of Medical Education and Research

brief_summary.textblock: Corona virus disease 2019 (COVID 19), first identified in December 2019 in a cluster of population in a Chinese province, soon emerged as a pandemic, causing a huge strain on healthcare system and mortality all over the world. An ideal marker for predicting course of this illness should be easily available and reproducible; as the disease burden has spread to third world countries whose healthcare system is resource limited. Our study is aimed to study the utility of lymphocyte- monocyte ratio in the early stages to predict the progression of COVID 19 pneumonia.

primary_outcome.description: disease progression equal or more than 2 stages

secondary_outcome.description: end outcome of the patients diagnosed of COVID-19 infection

arm_group.description: Cohort A with patients who progressed to next stage of illness or continue to remain in the same stage
Cohort B with those who improved by two points on the ordinal scale without any further progression

intervention.description: Absolute lymphicyte and absolute monocyte counts are recorded on admission of COVID -19 positive patient and ratio is derived. the patients are followed up for any progression of disease stage.

study_pop.textblock: all patients who are tested positive for COVID 19 and presented within 7 days of symptom onset will be included

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- All adults of age 18-80 years tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 reverse-transcriptase - polymerase chain reaction (rt-PCR) and presented within 7 days of symptom(s) onset
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnancy
- Sepsis
- Malignancy
- Patients on immunosuppressant therapy
- Chronic inflammatory conditions
- Cases lost to follow up
